Line 77: Line 77:
The Great Basin's two most populous metropolitan areas are [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]] to the west and [[Salt Lake City]] on the east side. The area between these two cities is sparsely populated, but includes the smaller cities of [[Delta, Utah|Delta]], [[Elko, Nevada|Elko]], [[Ely, Nevada|Ely]], [[Tonopah, Nevada|Tonopah]], [[Wendover, Utah|Wendover]], [[West Wendover, Nevada|West Wendover]], and [[Winnemucca, Nevada|Winnemucca]]. The southern area of the basin has the communities of [[Palmdale]], [[Victorville]], and [[Palm Springs]]. Major roadways traversing the Great Basin include [[Interstate 80]], [[Interstate 15]], [[U.S. Route 6]], [[U.S. Route 50]], [[U.S. Route 93]], [[U.S. Route 95]] and [[U.S. Route 395]], with the Nevada section of U.S. Route 50 nicknamed "The Loneliest Road in America".<ref name=ncot>{{cite web |url = http://travelnevada.com/documents/guides/survival_guide.pdf |title = The Official Hwy 50 Survival Guide â The Loneliest Road in America |accessdate = 2007-12-15 |publisher = Nevada Commission on Tourism |format=PDF}}</ref> Railroad transportation routes also pass through Reno and Salt Lake City.{{Dubious|Not notable relative to Great Basin--railroads pass through lots of Great Basin communities|date=October 2011}}
The Great Basin's two most populous metropolitan areas are [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]] to the west and [[Salt Lake City]] on the east side. The area between these two cities is sparsely populated, but includes the smaller cities of [[Delta, Utah|Delta]], [[Elko, Nevada|Elko]], [[Ely, Nevada|Ely]], [[Tonopah, Nevada|Tonopah]], [[Wendover, Utah|Wendover]], [[West Wendover, Nevada|West Wendover]], and [[Winnemucca, Nevada|Winnemucca]]. The southern area of the basin has the communities of [[Palmdale]], [[Victorville]], and [[Palm Springs]]. Major roadways traversing the Great Basin include [[Interstate 80]], [[Interstate 15]], [[U.S. Route 6]], [[U.S. Route 50]], [[U.S. Route 93]], [[U.S. Route 95]] and [[U.S. Route 395]], with the Nevada section of U.S. Route 50 nicknamed "The Loneliest Road in America".<ref name=ncot>{{cite web |url = http://travelnevada.com/documents/guides/survival_guide.pdf |title = The Official Hwy 50 Survival Guide â The Loneliest Road in America |accessdate = 2007-12-15 |publisher = Nevada Commission on Tourism |format=PDF}}</ref> Railroad transportation routes also pass through Reno and Salt Lake City.{{Dubious|Not notable relative to Great Basin--railroads pass through lots of Great Basin communities|date=October 2011}}
  +   +
===Hydrology===
  +
[[File:WahWah.JPG|thumb|left|[[Wah Wah Valley]], [[Utah]], thunderstorm{{Dubious|Why is an image of a thunderstorm notable?|date=October 2011}}]]
  +
[[Image:WheelerSnow.JPG|thumb|left|Great Basin snowstorm in the [[Snake Valley (Great Basin)|Snake Valley]] of Utah and Nevada]]
  +
The [[Great Basin Divide]] separates the Great Basin from the watersheds draining to the Pacific Ocean. The southernmost portion of the Great Basin is the watershed area of the [[Laguna Salada (Mexico)|Laguna Salada]]. The Great Basin's longest and largest river is the [[Bear River (Utah)|Bear River]] of {{convert|350|mi|km|abbr=on}},<ref name=Bear>{{cite web |title=Bear River Watershed Description |url=http://www.bearriverinfo.org/description/ |publisher=[[Bear River (Utah)|Bear River]] Watershed Information System |accessdate=2010-04-28}} (an additional ~1% is in the SW corner of WY)</ref> and the largest single watershed is the [[Humboldt River]] drainage of roughly {{convert|17000|sqmi|km2|abbr=on}}. Most Great Basin precipitation is snow, and the precipitation that neither evaporates nor is taken for human use will sink into [[groundwater]] [[aquifer]]s, while evaporation of collected water occurs from [[sink (geography)|geographic sinks]].<ref name=NPS>{{cite web |title=Great Basin |url=http://www.nature.nps.gov/Geology/usgsnps/province/brgrbas.html |work=Geologic Provinces of the United States: Basin and Range Province |location=nature.nps.gov |publisher=[[National Park Service]] |accessdate=2009-01-10}}</ref> [[Lake Tahoe]], North America's largest [[alpine lake]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Amazing Lake Tahoe |url=http://www.bluelaketahoe.com/page.php?p=amaz&l=1 |publisher=Lake Tahoe Visitors Authority |accessdate=2008-10-26}}</ref> is part of the Great Basin's central [[Lake Lahontan|Lahontan]] subregion. Great Basin named deserts include the [[Black Rock Desert]], the [[Great Salt Lake Desert]], the [[Sevier Lake|Sevier Desert]], the [[Smoke Creek Desert]], [[Nevada salt deserts]] in the [[Great Basin Province]], the [[Mojave Desert]], and part of the [[Sonoran Desert]].
  +   +
[[File:TuleHorses.JPG|thumb|left|The [[Tule Valley, Utah|Tule Valley watershed]] and the [[House Range]] ([[Notch Peak]]) are part of the Great Basin's Great Salt Lake [[Hydrological code#United States|hydrologic unit]]]]
==Ecology==
==Ecology==
Although mostly within the [[North American Desert]] ecoregion, portions of the Great Basin extend into the [[List of ecoregions in the United States (EPA)|Forested Mountain and Mediterranean California]] ecoregions. The [[semi-arid climate|semi-arid areas]] of the [[List of ecoregions in North America (CEC)|Forested Mountain ecoregion]] include the [[White Mountains (California)|White Mountains]] and [[Inyo Mountains]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} Extending north of the [[42nd parallel north]], the [[Northern Basin and Range (ecoregion)]] has its southern border at the highest shoreline of the [[Pleistocene]] [[Lake Bonneville]]. The south edge of the Central Basin and Range ecoregion is in Nevada, north of the south edge of the [[Great Basin section]].
Although mostly within the [[North American Desert]] ecoregion, portions of the Great Basin extend into the [[List of ecoregions in the United States (EPA)|Forested Mountain and Mediterranean California]] ecoregions. The [[semi-arid climate|semi-arid areas]] of the [[List of ecoregions in North America (CEC)|Forested Mountain ecoregion]] include the [[White Mountains (California)|White Mountains]] and [[Inyo Mountains]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} Extending north of the [[42nd parallel north]], the [[Northern Basin and Range (ecoregion)]] has its southern border at the highest shoreline of the [[Pleistocene]] [[Lake Bonneville]]. The south edge of the Central Basin and Range ecoregion is in Nevada, north of the south edge of the [[Great Basin section]].
  +   +
===Fauna===
  +
Great Basin wildlife includes [[Pronghorn]], [[Mule Deer]], [[Mountain Lion]], and [[Lagomorph]]s such as [[Black-tailed Jackrabbit]] and [[Desert Cottontail]] and the [[coyote]]s that prey on them. [[Packrat]]s, [[Kangaroo rat]]s and other small rodents are also common, but these are predominantly nocturnal. [[Elk]] and [[Bighorn Sheep]] are present but uncommon. Small [[lizards]] such as the [[Great Basin fence lizard]], [[Longnose Leopard Lizard]] and [[Horned Lizard]] are common, especially in lower elevations. [[Rattlesnake]]s and [[Gopher snake]]s are also present. The [[Inyo Mountains Salamander]] is endangered. Shorebirds such as [[Phalarope]]s and [[Curlew]]s can be found in wet areas. [[American White Pelican]]s are common at [[Pyramid Lake (Nevada)|Pyramid Lake]]. [[Golden Eagle]]s are perhaps more common in the Great Basin than anywhere else in the US.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} [[Mourning Dove]], [[Western Meadowlark]], [[Black-billed Magpie]], and [[Common Raven]] are other common bird species.
  +   +
Two [[endangered species]] of fish are found in Pyramid Lake: the [[Cui-ui]] [[Catostomidae|sucker fish]] and the [[Lahontan cutthroat trout]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Hogan |first=C.Michael |coauthor=Papineau, Marc, et al |year=1987 |title=Development of a dynamic water quality simulation model for the [[Truckee River]] |publisher=Earth Metrics Inc. |series=[[Environmental Protection Agency]] Technology Series |location=Washington D.C.|page=}}{{Verify source|Does this book actually have any of the facts in this wikiarticle|date=January 2008}}</ref>
  +   +
Large [[invertebrates]] include [[tarantula]]s ([[Aphonopelma]] genus) and [[Mormon cricket]]s. Exotic species, including [[Chukar]], [[Grey Partridge]], and [[Himalayan Snowcock]], have been successfully introduced to the Great Basin, although the latter has only thrived in the [[Ruby Mountains]]. [[Drooping Brome|Cheatgrass]], an [[invasive species]] which was unintentionally introduced, forms a critical portion of their diets. [[Feral]] [[horse]]s ([[Mustang (horse)|Mustangs]]) and wild [[burro]]s are other highly reproductive, and ecosystem controversial, alien species. Most of the Great Basin is [[Rangeland|open range]] and domestic [[cattle]] and [[sheep]] are widespread.
